title: Case 5 – The Gallery After Dark
brief:
Midnight at Lindsay’s gallery — champagne chatter, velvet ropes, paintings lit like confessions. The victim raises a glass during the final toast, smiles… and folds to the floor.

Poison — silent, elegant, no struggle. In a room full of witnesses, someone slipped death into crystal.

ZOE ran the bar.
LINDSAY curated the night.
VERONICA stood glowing beneath spotlights — star of the exhibition.

Three hands touched the glasses. Only one needed applause enough to kill for it.
wrenHint:
Watch the performance, not the stage.

• Everyone’s eyes were on Veronica during her big speech — except when the lights dipped for her projection piece.
• The poison matches a cleaning agent kept behind Zoe’s bar — but it’s missing only a thimble.
• Lindsay stayed glued to donors… until that jammed curtain dragged her across the room.

Someone needed a moment unobserved — and the blackout gave her center stage.

zoe: Bar was chaos. Orders everywhere. I shake, pour, smile — that is the job. No time for murder between refills and broken champagne corks.
He wanted something fancy, then complained it was too sweet. I remember him because he tipped coins instead of notes. That is not motive — that is Tuesday.
If my prints are on his glass, of course they are — I served half the room. But the agent you found is under lock and rag. Bar staff do not touch cleaner during service.
lindsay: A host never rests. Donors want hands shaken, sponsors want praise, lights want miracles. I do not stand still long enough to poison toast and make it look graceful.
He financed this exhibition, but he wanted naming rights large enough to cover the moon. We argued — yes — but a dead patron funds nothing.
Fingerprints? Mine are on every table, every glass, every frame. I set the place myself. If you chase prints, you will drown in mine. Timing matters more than touch.
veronica: I drifted between admirers, spoke poetry about canvas and silence. When the projection began, the room dimmed — my world for twenty seconds. The audience watched light, not hands.
He saved my show when no one else would. In return he wanted everything — attention, ownership, credit written in glitter. He loved art the way gamblers love debt collectors.

We toasted. He raised his glass too high. I sipped — then smiled — then returned it to his hand when the cameras turned. If something else entered the drink afterward, it wasn’t from mine… unless it was already there.

successEnding:
{culprit}'s poise cracks when you replay the blackout.

Twenty seconds of darkness. Her glass in his hand. A dressing-room bottle of cleaner missing just enough to kill — subtle, theatrical, bitter as applause withheld.
Crowd gasps become alibis. She needed him alive until the speech… and silent after.

Security escorts her past her own paintings — all eyes finally on the star she made herself.
failureEnding:
You fix on {accused} — the barmaid too close to the cleaner, or the curator who vanished behind a curtain.
They fumble explanations until one sticks enough for custody.

Hours later, Wren calls. The projection blackout, the swapped glass, the missing agent — every line draws back to {culprit} instead.
Her show opens tomorrow, critics flocking. The city calls it brilliance.
Only you know the price of the performance.
